dependency.name: gender-of-nouns
dependency.description: Spanish nouns are grammatically masculine or feminine; agreement for articles, adjectives, and some determiners follows noun gender.

concept.name: definite-indefinite-articles
concept.description: Articles mark definiteness (the vs a/an) and agree in gender/number with nouns.

dependency.name: gender-of-nouns
dependency.description: Spanish nouns are grammatically masculine or feminine; agreement for articles, adjectives, and some determiners follows noun gender.

concept.name: adjective-agreement-position
concept.description: Adjectives agree in gender and number with the nouns they modify; their position (pre- or post-nominal) can affect emphasis or meaning.

dependency.name: gender-of-nouns
dependency.description: Spanish nouns are grammatically masculine or feminine; agreement for articles, adjectives, and some determiners follows noun gender.

concept.name: demonstratives
concept.description: Demonstrative determiners/pronouns indicate proximity (este/esta/estos/estas = near speaker; ese/esa/… = near listener; aquel/aquella/… = far). Neuter forms esto/eso/aquello refer to ideas.

dependency.name: gender-of-nouns
dependency.description: Spanish nouns are grammatically masculine or feminine; agreement for articles, adjectives, and some determiners follows noun gender.

concept.name: possessive-adjectives-pronouns
concept.description: Possessives mark ownership and agree with the possessed noun in gender/number (mi/mis, tu/tus, su/sus, nuestro/s). Possessive pronouns replace noun (el mío).

dependency.name: gender-of-nouns
dependency.description: Spanish nouns are grammatically masculine or feminine; agreement for articles, adjectives, and some determiners follows noun gender.

concept.name: numerals-ordinals
concept.description: Numerals (uno, dos, tres...) and ordinals (primero, segundo...) have agreement and contraction rules; uno becomes un before masculine noun.

dependency.name: gender-of-nouns
dependency.description: Spanish nouns are grammatically masculine or feminine; agreement for articles, adjectives, and some determiners follows noun gender.

concept.name: gender-agreement-error
concept.description: Addresses the common mistake of failing to match the gender of adjectives and articles to the nouns they modify.

dependency.name: gender-of-nouns
dependency.description: Spanish nouns are grammatically masculine or feminine; agreement for articles, adjectives, and some determiners follows noun gender.

concept.name: adverbs-adverbial-phrases
concept.description: Adverbs modify verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs; formed from adjectives with -mente or are simple invariants.

dependency.name: gender-of-nouns
dependency.description: Spanish nouns are grammatically masculine or feminine; agreement for articles, adjectives, and some determiners follows noun gender.

concept.name: participle-agreement-ser-estar
concept.description: Participles agree in gender/number with subject when used with ser in passive; with estar they describe resulting state and also agree.

dependency.name: plural-formation
dependency.description: Spanish marks singular vs plural in nouns, articles, adjectives and verbs through regular suffixation and agreement.

concept.name: definite-indefinite-articles
concept.description: Articles mark definiteness (the vs a/an) and agree in gender/number with nouns.

dependency.name: plural-formation
dependency.description: Spanish marks singular vs plural in nouns, articles, adjectives and verbs through regular suffixation and agreement.

concept.name: adjective-agreement-position
concept.description: Adjectives agree in gender and number with the nouns they modify; their position (pre- or post-nominal) can affect emphasis or meaning.

dependency.name: plural-formation
dependency.description: Spanish marks singular vs plural in nouns, articles, adjectives and verbs through regular suffixation and agreement.

concept.name: demonstratives
concept.description: Demonstrative determiners/pronouns indicate proximity (este/esta/estos/estas = near speaker; ese/esa/… = near listener; aquel/aquella/… = far). Neuter forms esto/eso/aquello refer to ideas.

dependency.name: plural-formation
dependency.description: Spanish marks singular vs plural in nouns, articles, adjectives and verbs through regular suffixation and agreement.

concept.name: possessive-adjectives-pronouns
concept.description: Possessives mark ownership and agree with the possessed noun in gender/number (mi/mis, tu/tus, su/sus, nuestro/s). Possessive pronouns replace noun (el mío).

dependency.name: plural-formation
dependency.description: Spanish marks singular vs plural in nouns, articles, adjectives and verbs through regular suffixation and agreement.

concept.name: numerals-ordinals
concept.description: Numerals (uno, dos, tres...) and ordinals (primero, segundo...) have agreement and contraction rules; uno becomes un before masculine noun.

dependency.name: plural-formation
dependency.description: Spanish marks singular vs plural in nouns, articles, adjectives and verbs through regular suffixation and agreement.

concept.name: agreement-compound-subjects
concept.description: Verb agreement is determined by the grammatical person and number of the subject; with compound subjects joined by y, verb is plural.

dependency.name: plural-formation
dependency.description: Spanish marks singular vs plural in nouns, articles, adjectives and verbs through regular suffixation and agreement.

concept.name: participle-agreement-ser-estar
concept.description: Participles agree in gender/number with subject when used with ser in passive; with estar they describe resulting state and also agree.

dependency.name: plural-formation
dependency.description: Spanish marks singular vs plural in nouns, articles, adjectives and verbs through regular suffixation and agreement.

concept.name: agreement-measure-expressions
concept.description: Expressions of measurement may treat numerals and unit phrases specially with singular/plural agreement.

dependency.name: definite-indefinite-articles
dependency.description: Articles mark definiteness (the vs a/an) and agree in gender/number with nouns.

concept.name: prepositions-contractions
concept.description: Prepositions link words and create complements; Spanish has fixed prepositions (a, de, en, por, para, con, sin, sobre, entre...). a + el → al; de + el → del.

dependency.name: indicative-simple-tenses
dependency.description: Indicative tenses express factual, real actions with different temporal/aspective distinctions: present, preterite, imperfect, future, conditional.

concept.name: subject-pronouns-pro-drop
concept.description: Spanish subject pronouns (yo, tú, él…) are often optional because verb inflections indicate person and number (pro-drop).

dependency.name: indicative-simple-tenses
dependency.description: Indicative tenses express factual, real actions with different temporal/aspective distinctions: present, preterite, imperfect, future, conditional.

concept.name: compound-perfect-tenses
concept.description: Perfects use haber + past participle to form present perfect, pluperfect, future perfect, conditional perfect. They express completed actions relative to a reference time.

dependency.name: indicative-simple-tenses
dependency.description: Indicative tenses express factual, real actions with different temporal/aspective distinctions: present, preterite, imperfect, future, conditional.

concept.name: future-tense
concept.description: The simple future is a synthetic future; ir a + infinitive forms a near future/periphrastic future often used in spoken Spanish.

dependency.name: indicative-simple-tenses
dependency.description: Indicative tenses express factual, real actions with different temporal/aspective distinctions: present, preterite, imperfect, future, conditional.

concept.name: conditional-tense
concept.description: Conditional expresses hypothetical outcomes or politeness; conditional perfect expresses hypothetical actions in the past.

dependency.name: indicative-simple-tenses
dependency.description: Indicative tenses express factual, real actions with different temporal/aspective distinctions: present, preterite, imperfect, future, conditional.

concept.name: preterite-imperfect-misuse
concept.description: Addresses the frequent error of using the wrong past tense to describe an action (completed vs. ongoing/habitual).

dependency.name: indicative-simple-tenses
dependency.description: Indicative tenses express factual, real actions with different temporal/aspective distinctions: present, preterite, imperfect, future, conditional.

concept.name: lexical-vs-grammatical-aspect
concept.description: Lexical aspect (states, activities, accomplishments, achievements) interacts with tense/aspect choices and with preterite/imperfect distinction.

dependency.name: lexical-vs-grammatical-aspect
dependency.description: Lexical aspect (states, activities, accomplishments, achievements) interacts with tense/aspect choices and with preterite/imperfect distinction.

concept.name: preterite-imperfect-misuse
concept.description: Addresses the frequent error of using the wrong past tense to describe an action (completed vs. ongoing/habitual).

dependency.name: ser-vs-estar
dependency.description: Two copulas with different uses: ser generally for inherent/permanent characteristics, identity, origin, time; estar for states, locations, and progressive aspect.

concept.name: ser-estar-confusion
concept.description: Addresses the common mistake of incorrectly choosing between 'ser' (for permanent states) and 'estar' (for temporary states/locations).

dependency.name: ser-vs-estar
dependency.description: Two copulas with different uses: ser generally for inherent/permanent characteristics, identity, origin, time; estar for states, locations, and progressive aspect.

concept.name: passive-voice
concept.description: The grammatical passive uses ser + participle (agreed in gender/number) to focus on the patient; se passives are agentless passives common in Spanish.

dependency.name: ser-vs-estar
dependency.description: Two copulas with different uses: ser generally for inherent/permanent characteristics, identity, origin, time; estar for states, locations, and progressive aspect.

concept.name: participle-agreement-ser-estar
concept.description: Participles agree in gender/number with subject when used with ser in passive; with estar they describe resulting state and also agree.

dependency.name: direct-indirect-object-pronouns
dependency.description: Object pronouns replace direct/indirect objects and cliticize before conjugated verbs or attach to infinitives/gerunds/affirmative imperatives.

concept.name: clitic-order-combinations
concept.description: When two clitic pronouns appear, order and phonological adjustments apply.

dependency.name: direct-indirect-object-pronouns
dependency.description: Object pronouns replace direct/indirect objects and cliticize before conjugated verbs or attach to infinitives/gerunds/affirmative imperatives.

concept.name: se-lo-construction
concept.description: For sequences le + lo/la/los/las the indirect pronoun le/les changes to se to avoid clashing sounds.

dependency.name: direct-indirect-object-pronouns
dependency.description: Object pronouns replace direct/indirect objects and cliticize before conjugated verbs or attach to infinitives/gerunds/affirmative imperatives.

concept.name: gustar-like-verbs
concept.description: Verbs like gustar have experiencer as indirect object and the thing liked as subject; thus they conjugate according to the thing liked.

dependency.name: direct-indirect-object-pronouns
dependency.description: Object pronouns replace direct/indirect objects and cliticize before conjugated verbs or attach to infinitives/gerunds/affirmative imperatives.

concept.name: leismo-loismo-laismo
concept.description: Use of le as masculine direct object (le instead of lo) — common in parts of Spain; loísmo/laísmo other regionally marked variants.

dependency.name: direct-indirect-object-pronouns
dependency.description: Object pronouns replace direct/indirect objects and cliticize before conjugated verbs or attach to infinitives/gerunds/affirmative imperatives.

concept.name: clitic-doubling
concept.description: Some varieties double objects with clitic pronouns plus full noun phrase (Le di a María el libro — Le doubles a María).

dependency.name: direct-indirect-object-pronouns
dependency.description: Object pronouns replace direct/indirect objects and cliticize before conjugated verbs or attach to infinitives/gerunds/affirmative imperatives.

concept.name: negative-imperative-pronoun-placement
concept.description: Affirmative imperatives attach pronouns; negative imperatives place pronouns before the verb.

dependency.name: reflexive-pronouns-verbs
dependency.description: Reflexive pronouns (me, te, se, nos, os, se) indicate the subject both performs and receives the action (or lexical pronominal verbs).

concept.name: reciprocal-se
concept.description: Reciprocal use of se expresses mutual actions: nos/se with plural subjects.

dependency.name: reflexive-pronouns-verbs
dependency.description: Reflexive pronouns (me, te, se, nos, os, se) indicate the subject both performs and receives the action (or lexical pronominal verbs).

concept.name: accidental-se
concept.description: Se + indirect object pronoun expresses accidental occurrences where subject 'loses' control: Se me olvidó.

dependency.name: reflexive-pronouns-verbs
dependency.description: Reflexive pronouns (me, te, se, nos, os, se) indicate the subject both performs and receives the action (or lexical pronominal verbs).

concept.name: impersonal-se
concept.description: Se used to make general statements without specifying the agent: English passive/impersonal 'one/they/people'.

dependency.name: reflexive-pronouns-verbs
dependency.description: Reflexive pronouns (me, te, se, nos, os, se) indicate the subject both performs and receives the action (or lexical pronominal verbs).

concept.name: passive-voice
concept.description: The grammatical passive uses ser + participle (agreed in gender/number) to focus on the patient; se passives are agentless passives common in Spanish.

dependency.name: impersonal-se
dependency.description: Se used to make general statements without specifying the agent: English passive/impersonal 'one/they/people'.

concept.name: passive-voice
concept.description: The grammatical passive uses ser + participle (agreed in gender/number) to focus on the patient; se passives are agentless passives common in Spanish.

dependency.name: subjunctive-mood
dependency.description: The subjunctive expresses non-factual or non-asserted situations: wishes, doubts, emotions, recommendations, hypothetical or irrealis contexts.

concept.name: subjunctive-adjective-clauses
concept.description: In adjective clauses, the subjunctive is used when the antecedent is unknown, nonexistent, or indefinite.

dependency.name: subjunctive-mood
dependency.description: The subjunctive expresses non-factual or non-asserted situations: wishes, doubts, emotions, recommendations, hypothetical or irrealis contexts.

concept.name: subjunctive-with-conjunctions
concept.description: Certain subordinating conjunctions always (or often) trigger the subjunctive because they introduce uncertainty, purpose, or contingency (para que, a menos que, en caso de que, antes de que).

dependency.name: subjunctive-mood
dependency.description: The subjunctive expresses non-factual or non-asserted situations: wishes, doubts, emotions, recommendations, hypothetical or irrealis contexts.

concept.name: imperative-commands
concept.description: Imperative mood expresses commands; affirmative and negative forms use different pronoun placement rules and sometimes different forms (e.g., irregulars).

dependency.name: subjunctive-mood
dependency.description: The subjunctive expresses non-factual or non-asserted situations: wishes, doubts, emotions, recommendations, hypothetical or irrealis contexts.

concept.name: si-clauses
concept.description: Si clauses categorize real/possible/past counterfactual conditions and determine tense combinations.

dependency.name: subjunctive-mood
dependency.description: The subjunctive expresses non-factual or non-asserted situations: wishes, doubts, emotions, recommendations, hypothetical or irrealis contexts.

concept.name: sequence-of-tenses
concept.description: In subordinate clauses, the tense/mood of verbs depends on the tense/mood of the main clause (backshift rules).

dependency.name: subjunctive-mood
dependency.description: The subjunctive expresses non-factual or non-asserted situations: wishes, doubts, emotions, recommendations, hypothetical or irrealis contexts.

concept.name: reported-speech
concept.description: Indirect speech reports what someone said and frequently requires tense/mood changes (backshifting).

dependency.name: subjunctive-mood
dependency.description: The subjunctive expresses non-factual or non-asserted situations: wishes, doubts, emotions, recommendations, hypothetical or irrealis contexts.

concept.name: subjunctive-indicative-misuse
concept.description: Addresses the common mistake of using the indicative mood in clauses that require the subjunctive (e.g., after expressions of doubt, desire).

dependency.name: conditional-tense
dependency.description: Conditional expresses hypothetical outcomes or politeness; conditional perfect expresses hypothetical actions in the past.

concept.name: si-clauses
concept.description: Si clauses categorize real/possible/past counterfactual conditions and determine tense combinations.

dependency.name: sequence-of-tenses
dependency.description: In subordinate clauses, the tense/mood of verbs depends on the tense/mood of the main clause (backshift rules).

concept.name: reported-speech
concept.description: Indirect speech reports what someone said and frequently requires tense/mood changes (backshifting).

dependency.name: gerunds-participles
dependency.description: Gerunds (-ando, -iendo) express continuous/progressive actions; participles (-ado, -ido) form perfect tenses and adjectives.

concept.name: compound-perfect-tenses
concept.description: Perfects use haber + past participle to form present perfect, pluperfect, future perfect, conditional perfect. They express completed actions relative to a reference time.

dependency.name: gerunds-participles
dependency.description: Gerunds (-ando, -iendo) express continuous/progressive actions; participles (-ado, -ido) form perfect tenses and adjectives.

concept.name: verbal-periphrasis
concept.description: Periphrastic constructions combine auxiliary verbs and non-finite verb forms to express aspect, obligation, progression, or intention.

dependency.name: gerunds-participles
dependency.description: Gerunds (-ando, -iendo) express continuous/progressive actions; participles (-ado, -ido) form perfect tenses and adjectives.

concept.name: passive-voice
concept.description: The grammatical passive uses ser + participle (agreed in gender/number) to focus on the patient; se passives are agentless passives common in Spanish.

dependency.name: gerunds-participles
dependency.description: Gerunds (-ando, -iendo) express continuous/progressive actions; participles (-ado, -ido) form perfect tenses and adjectives.

concept.name: participle-agreement-ser-estar
concept.description: Participles agree in gender/number with subject when used with ser in passive; with estar they describe resulting state and also agree.

dependency.name: gerunds-participles
dependency.description: Gerunds (-ando, -iendo) express continuous/progressive actions; participles (-ado, -ido) form perfect tenses and adjectives.

concept.name: neuter-article-lo
concept.description: Lo is a neuter nominaliser used before adjectives/participles to form abstract nouns or to mean 'what/that which'.

dependency.name: modal-verbs
dependency.description: Modals express ability, obligation, necessity, or probability (e.g., poder, deber, querer).

concept.name: verbal-periphrasis
concept.description: Periphrastic constructions combine auxiliary verbs and non-finite verb forms to express aspect, obligation, progression, or intention.

dependency.name: verbal-periphrasis
dependency.description: Periphrastic constructions combine auxiliary verbs and non-finite verb forms to express aspect, obligation, progression, or intention.

concept.name: causative-constructions
concept.description: Hacer and dejar can be used to indicate causing someone to do something or allowing something to happen.

dependency.name: orthographic-accents
dependency.description: Accent marks (tilde) mark stressed syllables irregular to default stress rules and distinguish homographs (tú (you) vs tu (your)).

concept.name: interrogatives-accent-marks
concept.description: Interrogative and exclamative words (qué, quién, cuándo, cómo, cuánto, por qué, cuál) are accented when used in direct/indirect questions or exclamations.

dependency.name: orthographic-accents
dependency.description: Accent marks (tilde) mark stressed syllables irregular to default stress rules and distinguish homographs (tú (you) vs tu (your)).

concept.name: relative-vs-interrogative-pronouns
concept.description: Interrogative/exclamative forms carry an accent (e.g., qué), while relative pronouns do not. Distinguishes qué (what) vs que (that).

dependency.name: relative-pronouns
dependency.description: Words that introduce relative (adjective) clauses and relate clauses to antecedents.

concept.name: relative-vs-interrogative-pronouns
concept.description: Interrogative/exclamative forms carry an accent (e.g., qué), while relative pronouns do not. Distinguishes qué (what) vs que (that).

dependency.name: interrogatives-accent-marks
dependency.description: Interrogative and exclamative words (qué, quién, cuándo, cómo, cuánto, por qué, cuál) are accented when used in direct/indirect questions or exclamations.

concept.name: relative-vs-interrogative-pronouns
concept.description: Interrogative/exclamative forms carry an accent (e.g., qué), while relative pronouns do not. Distinguishes qué (what) vs que (that).

dependency.name: conjunctions
dependency.description: Conjunctions link clauses/phrases; coordinating (y, pero, o) join equals; subordinating introduce dependent clauses (porque, aunque, cuando, si).

concept.name: subjunctive-with-conjunctions
concept.description: Certain subordinating conjunctions always (or often) trigger the subjunctive because they introduce uncertainty, purpose, or contingency (para que, a menos que, en caso de que, antes de que).

dependency.name: conjunctions
dependency.description: Conjunctions link clauses/phrases; coordinating (y, pero, o) join equals; subordinating introduce dependent clauses (porque, aunque, cuando, si).

concept.name: queismo-dequeismo
concept.description: Variation/error in using que vs de que in subordinate clauses; dequeísmo is inserting de unnecessarily, queísmo dropping necessary de.

dependency.name: prepositions-contractions
dependency.description: Prepositions link words and create complements; Spanish has fixed prepositions (a, de, en, por, para, con, sin, sobre, entre...). a + el → al; de + el → del.

concept.name: queismo-dequeismo
concept.description: Variation/error in using que vs de que in subordinate clauses; dequeísmo is inserting de unnecessarily, queísmo dropping necessary de.

dependency.name: por-vs-para
dependency.description: Two prepositions often translated as 'for' with different uses: por for cause, movement through, duration, exchange; para for purpose, destination, deadline, recipient.

concept.name: por-para-confusion
concept.description: Addresses the common difficulty in choosing the correct preposition, as both can translate to 'for' in English.

dependency.name: double-negatives
dependency.description: Spanish commonly uses double negatives (negative element + negative verb or pronoun) and this is grammatical (e.g., No veo nada).

concept.name: negative-polarity-items
concept.description: Words like nada, nadie, nunca, jamás, tampoco express negation and interact with no and sentence scope.

dependency.name: imperative-commands
dependency.description: Imperative mood expresses commands; affirmative and negative forms use different pronoun placement rules and sometimes different forms (e.g., irregulars).

concept.name: negative-imperative-pronoun-placement
concept.description: Affirmative imperatives attach pronouns; negative imperatives place pronouns before the verb.

dependency.name: usted-vs-tu
dependency.description: Choice of usted vs tú signals formality, social distance, or politeness.

concept.name: voseo-vosotros-ustedes
concept.description: Regional variants affect pronoun use and verb forms: voseo uses vos, vosotros used in Spain for informal plural you, ustedes used in Latin America for both formal/informal plural you.

dependency.name: usted-vs-tu
dependency.description: Choice of usted vs tú signals formality, social distance, or politeness.

concept.name: politeness-formal
concept.description: Use of formal address (usted/ustedes), polite requests (conditional tense), and other formal conversational structures.

dependency.name: usted-vs-tu
dependency.description: Choice of usted vs tú signals formality, social distance, or politeness.

concept.name: politeness-informal
concept.description: Use of informal address (tú/vosotros), casual greetings, and common informal conversational patterns.

dependency.name: subject-pronouns-pro-drop
dependency.description: Spanish subject pronouns (yo, tú, él…) are often optional because verb inflections indicate person and number (pro-drop).

concept.name: voseo-vosotros-ustedes
concept.description: Regional variants affect pronoun use and verb forms: voseo uses vos, vosotros used in Spain for informal plural you, ustedes used in Latin America for both formal/informal plural you.

dependency.name: agreement-compound-subjects
dependency.description: Verb agreement is determined by the grammatical person and number of the subject; with compound subjects joined by y, verb is plural.

concept.name: gustar-like-verbs
concept.description: Verbs like gustar have experiencer as indirect object and the thing liked as subject; thus they conjugate according to the thing liked.

dependency.name: interjection-exclamation
dependency.description: Short exclamations that express a sudden feeling or reaction (e.g., '¡Ay!', '¡Ojalá!', '¡Qué va!').

concept.name: inverted-punctuation
concept.description: Spanish uses inverted question and exclamation marks at the start (¿ ¡) and closing marks at end; punctuation interacts with grammar for emphasis.
